data.title: #16770 Delimit compound shortcuts with commas
data.body:
Implements #16770

Changes the display of compound keyboard shortcuts to separate various parts of a chord with a comma, instead of just a space.

To prevent confusion for commands that have multiple keyboard shortcuts, the command palette will now only show the first keyboard shortcut, instead of all of them.

*Note*: I made a change to `quickCommand.ts` because it was also concatenating the keyboard shortcuts with a space, however that class doesn't seem to actually be used anywhere.

data.title: Markdown: slight flickering in preview while editing
data.body:
Follow up from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19351, there is still a little bit of flickering when editing a markdown file while having the preview open.

My setup:
* editing our release notes (that is some good amount of text with images)
* zoom level 1

Would be awesome if it was possible to avoid flicker alltogether.

data.title: Terminal flowControl setting default should check for the existence of ~/.oh-my-zsh
data.body:
This would handle the main edge case better, right now flow control is disabled completely by default on all `zsh` shells.

Context: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18833

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Missing Recent section unbalances layout
data.body: Recent is removed when there are no recent folders. Could instead keep the section and indicate that there are no recent folder.

data.title: The integrated terminal uses fish shell and it lacks the auto completion. Also the working directory doesn't mounts by itself ,have to cd into the directory.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15014
The integrated terminal uses fish shell and it lacks the auto completion. Sometimes the terminal hangs for few seconds on tab completion. Also, the working directory doesn't mount by itself , have to cd into the directory.

data.title: Close window dialogue gets shown multiple times on pressing 'Cancel'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Sierra 10.12.2

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Create a new file
2. Put something into that file so that it brings up a dialogue when trying to close it
3. Press cmd-w (close window) multiple times
4. Click cancel

The same dialogue will come up multiple times rather than cancelling the rest of the stack of close commands.

**Possible expected results:**
- The rest of the commands are removed
- The focus moves to the next tab upon pressing cancel and that one is attempted to be closed instead

data.title: Log preferences filter strings that produced no results
data.body: Included in the existing telemetry event.

data.body:
Request from C#/OmniSharp team, grammar is now maintained in an OSS repo:

https://github.com/dotnet/csharp-tmLanguage

data.title: Intermittent Frontend Display Failing to Update

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: code_1.8.1-1482158209_amd64.deb
- OS Version (All Debian): Linux devlap 4.7.0-0.bpo.1-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.7.8-1~bpo8+1 (2016-10-19) x86_64 GNU/Linux

Note: This does not happen on any of my Windows, or macOS devices - and is limited to Debian at this stage.

- Extensions: Omitted, as I've also tested with these disabled - and they differ between workstations.

- Project Language: Omitted, as this happens with any open project, and is not limited to anything in particular.

I've been using VSCode for some time, and seem to be plagued by this consistent, though unpredictable, freezing. This has been since day one, and present in at least 1.5.* of my version history.

I've attempted to investigate further, with the debugger open - however I cannot seem to gather anything unique about the case. In the few cases it's frozen with debugger open, the debugger is not available either. (Apologies; I've just found the persistent log option, and enabled)

I've tried running without extensions enabled, and have this issue with any language

It does happen on all three of my workstations running Debian release. The current workstation is running a backported kernel for unrelated reasons.

Steps to Reproduce:
 - Cannot provide. The freeze is intermittent.

data.title: I tried "Go to definition" and you won't believe what happened next
data.body:
- In vscode repo
- Open telemetryUtils.ts
- Line 270, `return configurationService.onDidUpdateConfiguration...`
- Cursor on `onDidUpdateConfiguration`
- Press F12
- It goes to the definition of the `Event` interface instead, in `vs/base/common/event`

data.title: Show warning on first load of workspace with typescript.tsdk setting
data.body:
Makes the following changes for selecting TS version:

* When a user first loads a workspace with either a `typescript.tsdk` setting in the workspace settings OR with a local version of TS, we show a TS version selector prompt. We use local storage to ensure we only show this alert on the first time you load a workspace.
* The selector now uses quick pick
*  When the user selects a new version, we now show a restart prompt afterwards:    
 
Please take a look at the pr and let me know if you have any further ideas on improving this flow

data.title: Find-all-references takes me to the wrong location when there is collapsed code.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18

Steps to Reproduce:

* Write:
```ts
function f() {





    g();




}


function g() {
}
```

* Collapse `function f()`.
* Find-all-refs on `function g()`.
* Double-click on the first reference.

![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19274678/22350457/b120a238-e3c8-11e6-9201-4f81c7332f0d.jpg)

This is just a simple example. My real problem is that in a large document with lots of collapsed code, I get taken to the wrong location when navigating with find-all-refs.

data.title: Workspace settings fail to load when opening root

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is the same as #18183, but for Mac/Linux instead of Windows.

- I open `/` in vscode
- Press the gear to create a launch config, fill it out and save it
- The dropdown still says "no configurations"

If I reload the window, the configs appear
If I rename a config and save it, the dropdown label doesn't update until I reload the window.

data.title: typescript.tsdk "must be a user setting"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0-insider (1.9.0-insider) 6ba4282fd27bacacbf8482472a0519560720fb9c 2017-01-26T07:24:06.051Z

- OS Version: OSX 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any project that's been working fine for a long time with today's new insiders build
2. Observe error

As of today's new insiders build, VSCode  no longer accepts the cut the following very common settings:

```
  "typescript.check.workspaceVersion": false,
  "typescript.tsdk": "node_modules/typescript/lib"
```

As documented:

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions

So this is both a bug report and a question. The question is how to achieve the following. The bug report is that there does not appear to be a way to achieve it.

Many of us work on many different projects with considerable version skew of the underlying libraries and tooling. This is a per project fact, not a per developer fact. There needs to be away to specify:

* Inside a project
* in the source code of the project, not in some other settings that a developer must learn about and then go adjust somewhere
* ideally, right here in the settings file, seems like the most reasonable place
* The fact that for this project it is desirable to use the same TypeScript version for IDE support as is used in the project itself.

There seems to be a new behavior in which as a user I am asked to click in the status bar to try to ask Code to use a certain version. That is a slightly nice developer experience, but it misses the point of the above.

Is there a new way to specify this thing that the old settings specified? (Or better yet, is there a way to make it just be the default that always happens all the time?  Offhand it seems that using a **different** version of TypeScript for IDE support than a project uses to compile, should be the unusual case requiring a special setting and jumping through hoops.)

data.title: Warning for c_cpp_properties.json

- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0-insider (1.9.0-insider)
- OS Version: Mac OSX Sierra
